titleStmt.title: R. F. Stone et al. to Beriah Magoffin
CWG9750

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Beriah Magoffin: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons and Remissions, 1859-1862

body.p:
Benton Ky.
Decr 1860
To His Excellency
Beriah Magoffin, Govenor of Kentucky

The undersigned Citizens of Marshall County Kentucky, would most respectfully represent and state to your Excellency That at the September Term of the Marshall Equity & Criminal Court 1860 there was a Judgment rendered against William Clark of our County for Retailing Spirituous Liquors to the amount of Twenty Dollars -- Now ^we^ will State that it was understood and generally beleived that Mr Clark had had a legislative act passed authorizing him thus to sell without a license, and that he thought he was not violating the law -- in which however he was mistaken,

Mr Clark is a blind man and has been unable to see for a number of years -- has a wife and Six ^small^ children to support -- he has no means except as arises from the labor of his wife & little children
It may appear to be a small amt to present to your Excellency, but with him it is a matter of importance --
Mr Clark has quit selling liquor, and he is a steady honorable man and
In Consideration of all the facts we pray that Your excellency remit said fine & as in duty &c we will ever pray &c

R. F. Stone
Philip Darnall
G. Darnall
W. A. Holland
S. D. Portis
A. T. Jones
A. A. Nelson
M, Riley
J M Dycus
